newsitem.title: USA: Fidelity Magellan cut stock holdings in June.
newsitem.headline: Fidelity Magellan cut stock holdings in June.

text.p: Fidelity Investments said Wednesday its Magellan Fund cut its exposure to the technology and energy stocks in June versus May, and raised holdings in finance and healthcare stocks.
According to Fidelity's monthly Mutual Fund Guide, Magellan cut its holdings in stocks to 93.9 percent of assets at the end of June versus 95.7 percent at the end of May.
Assets in cash and other investments rose to 6.0 percent of assets at the end of June from 4.2 percent at the end of May while convertibles remained unchanged at 0.1 percent of assets.

Magellan's holdings in technology stocks fell to 14.4 percent of assets at the end of June versus 15.2 percent at the May. Holdings in finance stocks rose to 11.9 percent from 11.4 percent, energy stocks dropped to 11.5 percent from 13.3 percent and healthcare stocks rose to 9.2 percent from 8.6 percent.
Holdings in most other sectors were largely unchanged over the month.
Magellan's assets rose to $58.3 billion at the end of June from $56.3 billion at the end of May.

Magellan's top 10 holdings at the end of June were General Electric Co, Philip Morris Cos Inc, Citicorp, Merck & Co Inc, International Business Machines Corp, Home Depot Inc, Oracle Corp, Microsoft Corp, CSX Corp, and BankAmerica Corp.
Bob Pozen, head of Fidelity's mutual funds division, told reporters early Wednesday that Magellan fund manager Robert Stansky has done a good job at aligning the fund he inherited in June 1996.
"I think that Magellan actually has done a very good job. He's had recently some very strong months," Pozen said.
